priest-allowcharselonce-desc:
The priest can grant you the right to change your class once — but not for free.

He demands a cleansing rite: track down and destroy those who defile the surroundings.

After the rite you will receive a blessing and can use .charsel once. You can only do this again after 720 in-game days.
priest-allowcharselonce-reward: Priest: The blessing is granted. You can now use .charsel once. Next time — in 720 in-game days.
priest-allowcharselonce-journal-text:
The priest in the temple offered a rare mercy: the right to change your class once.

But a blessing is never free.

He demands a cleansing rite:
Track down and destroy those who defile the surroundings.

The targets of the rite can vary; the priest will name new foes when you accept the task.

Complete the rite and return to receive the blessing.
priest-allowcharselonce-reward-journal-t:
The rite is complete.

The priest granted the blessing and allowed a single change of class and appearance.

Use the .charsel command when you are ready.
This can be done only once.

You will not be able to receive this permission again for at least 720 in-game days.
dialogue-priest-intro: Peace be with you. What do you seek here?
dialogue-priest-changeclass: I want to change my class.
dialogue-priest-aboutblessing: Tell me about the rite and the blessing.
dialogue-priest-close-answer: Go in peace. When you are ready, return.
no-quest-available-priest: The rite to change your class can be performed only once every 720 days.
no-quest-available-priest-cooldown: The rite to change your class will be available in {0} day(s).
dialogue-priest-whoareyou-answer: I have served here for many years. I do not seek power—only to keep people from despair and to remind them that order is still possible.
dialogue-priest-abouttemple-answer: You stand in the Church of the White Lotus, in the parish people call “Crossroads”. Here roads and fates meet: travelers find shelter, and the lost find a chance to begin again.
dialogue-priest-aboutblessing-answer: A blessing is not a coin. It has a cost: patience and deeds. The cleansing rite is simple—find those who defile the surroundings, and prove you can finish what you start.
dialogue-priest-final-text: The blessing is granted. You may now change class and appearance once via .charsel. You can only receive this again after 720 in-game days.
dialogue-witness-intro: The witness keeps silent, but the gaze is heavier than words.
dialogue-witness-openquests-confirm: Tell me what must be done.
dialogue-witness-whoareyou-answer: I observe and remember. That is enough.
dialogue-witness-aboutserver-answer:
Four people — four paths.

The Innkeeper offers work and reputation. He values silence and results.

The Priest guards the rite of rebirth. Prove yourself, and he will grant you one chance to use .charsel.

The Boss Hunter leads hunts into the crypts. He gives targets and teaches how to survive where stone remembers blood.

The Treasurer counts other people's mistakes like coins. You can buy land claim expansions and area slots from him — but he likes exams.
dialogue-arena-broker-openui-answer:
If you want numbers, take them. I only open the door. What you do with it is on you.

Interface is open.
dialogue-arena-broker-showregions-answer:
I put the list on the table.

If you see nothing, nobody has put any region up for rent. This is not a market of miracles: first a region must be declared, then paid for.
dialogue-arena-broker-help-answer:
Short version:

1) Open the interface — auctions and rent extension are there.
2) The list shows regions. Auction shows only free regions, extension shows only rented.
3) Bids and extensions cost rusty gears.
4) When an auction ends, the winner gets a 1-year rent and can extend up to 5 years.
5) If you miss the extension, the region returns to auction.
witness-introduction-desc:
The witness knows who does what at the Crossroads. He suggests a simple start: meet four people.

Talk to the Innkeeper, the Priest, the Boss Hunter, and the Treasurer.
witness-introduction-reward: Witness: Now you know where to go. Take 3 rusty gears — you will need them.
witness-introduction-journal-text:
The witness told me not to chase glory first. Start by learning who matters here.

1) Innkeeper: work and reputation.
2) Priest: rebirth rite and .charsel.
3) Boss Hunter: hunts into the crypts.
4) Treasurer: land claims and area slots for rusty gears.

I only need to talk to each of them.
witness-introduction-reward-journal-text:
I spoke with all four. Now it is clear: work with the Innkeeper, rebirth with the Priest, hunts with the Boss Hunter, and land claim matters with the Treasurer.

The witness gave me 3 rusty gears.
dialogue-witness-introduction-final-text: Remember. This place runs on deeds, not stories.
no-quest-available-witness: The witness has no work right now.
bosshunt-intro-desc: On a throne of yellowed vertebrae sits he — a living part of this place. From his decrepit robes wafts damp earth and eternity, and the cataracts on his eyes seem to see your skull through flesh. This is the Crypt Keeper, archivist of decay. He knows in which shadows doom slumbers, and is ready to point the way to those who value neither sanity nor blood. For him this is neither service nor help — it is an endless, viscous vigil over what should be forgotten.
bosshunt-intro-journal-text: I met the Crypt Keeper. This old man claims to know the paths to creatures that are the living embodiment of the dungeon's nightmares. He has no need for heroes in shining armor — they rust and break here first. He needs stubborn ones capable of gnawing stone with their teeth. He is ready to share knowledge, if I prove that my life is worth something in the eyes of eternity.
bosshunt-intro-complete-journal:
The Crypt Keeper handed me the Blood Meter. This is not a tool, but a curse enclosed in an artifact's form.

It pulses in the hand, heavy and warm, like a living organ. It is a parasite. Want to know where the enemy is? Feed it your blood. Ask too often — you will bleed out before reaching the target.

The old man explained: the marks scattered through the crypts are not safety signs, but scars on the dungeon's body. Places where the boundary has thinned. Follow them, but remember: creatures sense the warmth of living blood from afar. In these corridors there are no accidents. One wrong step, one extra sound — and you will add to the Ossuary's bone collection.
bosshunt-ossuarywarden-desc:
Hunt down and slay the Ossuary Warden. Use the tracker to follow its trail through bone dust and stale vows.

The hunter says the warden does not merely roam the crypts—it keeps them “alive”: wherever it passes, bones refuse to lie still and pull toward each other, as if trying to assemble new bodies. As long as it lives, the deep routes will close again and again, and missing travelers will become part of the ossuary.

It hates the light and tolerates no witnesses. Step too close, and the stone will remember your name.
bosshunt-ossuarywarden-journal-text:
The wanderer named the target: the Ossuary Warden.

It rises where the dark is thick and bone runs deep, as if the earth itself chose to become a grave. The crystal leads you through marked points—follow them and keep your distance: the warden strikes fast and without warning.

If the trail breaks, stop. Listen. In these places, silence knows how to lie.
bosshunt-ossuarywarden-reward-journal-te:
The warden has fallen. The dust settled, and for a moment the passages felt easier to breathe.

The wanderer says the path is clear for now, but the old things always return. Keep the crystal close—the hunt will begin again when the dark lifts bone once more.
bosshunt-use-tracker: Feed the Blood Meter to sense the enemy in the darkness.
bosshunt-tracker-received: The Blood Meter dug into the palm. Now you are bound. Every question to it is a wound, but the only way not to get lost.
bosshunt-ashenlurker-desc:
Your target is the Ashen Stalker. A mechanical horror created not by nature, but by someone's sick mind.

It avoids fair fight. Its tactic is chaos. It moves in jerks, disappearing into shadows and appearing where you don't expect it. But its main treachery — it defiles the very ground it walks on. Watch your feet: what it leaves behind can kill faster than its blades.

If you lose control of space, it will crush you with numbers and filth. Don't let it turn the battlefield into a trap.
bosshunt-ashenlurker-journal-text:
Hunt: Ashen Stalker.

A nimble and treacherous enemy. Beware not only its attacks, but the ground beneath your feet — it makes it deadly. Destroy everything it leaves behind, or you'll find yourself surrounded.
bosshunt-ashenlurker-reward-journal-text:
The clanging stopped. The mechanism froze forever, becoming a heap of useless iron.

The Crypt Keeper noted that such creatures feed on fuss and fear. "You made chaos fall silent," he said. The path ahead is open, but the shadows seem thicker.
bosshunt-ashenlurker-reward: The Stalker is dismantled. The Crypt Keeper warned: "Silence here lies. If you hear metal rustling behind you — strike without looking. Mechanisms can rust, but malice in them is eternal."
bosshunt-bonecolossus-desc:
Bring down the Ossuary Hound—a bone-wolf that guards the trails and tears the living apart for a single wrong step.

The wanderer says the hound did not appear by chance: someone “trained” it to the scent of blood and taught it to treat the crypts like its kennel. It drives prey toward the marks, cuts off the way back, and finishes those who slow down. As long as it lives, any run into the ossuary becomes a chase—and it always ends with someone left behind.

You will not hear it by its growl, but by the clatter of bone when it accelerates.
bosshunt-bonecolossus-journal-text:
The Ossuary Hound moves between the marks.

It does not hold ground like a man—it claims territory and pushes prey toward a convenient kill. Fast, relentless, and it will not let go once it tastes fear. The crystal points to the place it will return.

Do not stand still. If the hound enters a frenzy, it will press until you break.
bosshunt-bonecolossus-reward-journal-tex:
The hound fell, and the air held less of that dry grinding sound.

Silence returned—for now. The wanderer hinted such beasts return in cycles, as if someone releases them again and again to test the living.
bosshunt-subduction-maw-desc:
Slay the Subduction Maw — a rusted hunter that keeps its distance and bends the air with a sickening haze. It blinks through the shadows, scatters false echoes, and drowns the senses the closer it is to collapse.

Follow the marks and keep moving. The haze thickens as it weakens, and the last stretch is where most hunters lose their footing.
bosshunt-subduction-maw-journal-text:
Target: Subduction Maw.

It stalks between the marks, firing from range and retreating into the dark. When it is pushed hard, the air warps, copies appear, and the stink of oil turns into a fog that dulls the senses.

Do not stand still. The haze deepens as it bleeds.
bosshunt-subduction-maw-reward-journal-t:
The Subduction Maw collapsed in a hiss of oil and rust. The haze thinned, and the corridors felt clear again.

The wanderer nodded and warned: these hunters always return in another shape. Keep the crystal close and do not trust your own steps for long.
bosshunt-subduction-maw-reward: The Subduction Maw is defeated. The haze still lingers.
bosshunt-crypt-mirror-desc:
Your next target is the Crypt Mirror. It does not fight alone: it steals the faces and weapons of those who challenge it and forces them to duel their own echoes. The closer it is to collapse, the thicker the ring of impostors.

Stay with allies, keep moving, and do not let the copies box you in. They share one heart—strike any of them without hesitation.
bosshunt-crypt-mirror-journal-text:
Target: Crypt Mirror.

It mirrors fighters and their weapons. Anyone within its ritual receives a personal double, and they all bleed from the same heart. Do not waste time hunting the "real" one—damage to any copy wounds it.
bosshunt-crypt-mirror-reward-journal-tex:
The Crypt Mirror has fallen. Masks tore away, and the doubles dissolved into crypt dust.

The wanderer accepted the news calmly. He warned that deceivers return in other shadows. The crystal still remembers your blood.
bosshunt-crypt-mirror-reward: The Crypt Mirror is defeated. The echoes fade, but foreign footsteps still linger.
dialogue-bosshunter-intro: Looking for work—or a shadow that’s looking for you?
dialogue-bosshunter-whoareyou-answer: I take what the world leaves behind—tracks, bones, fear. Where wardens fall, stories start.
dialogue-bosshunter-about-answer: The Ossuary Warden doesn’t anchor to one place. We set marks so we can predict its path.
dialogue-bosshunter-whycrypts-answer: The crypts keep old vows and older rot. Trails are clearer there, and hiding is harder. The wardens rise from the deep again and again.
dialogue-bosshunter-howtracker-answer: The crystal cuts into the living. It doesn’t show a path—only distance. You pay in blood for every question.
dialogue-bosshunter-aboutreward-answer: The reward isn’t just coin. You get access to the trail and the right to hunt. That’s worth more than gold.
dialogue-bosshunter-aboutmarks-answer: The marks are places the wardens favor. We anchor them so we know where their next step begins.
dialogue-bosshunter-openquests-confirm: Listen carefully. It won’t forgive mistakes.
dialogue-bosshunter-close-answer: Don’t wait too long. Trails go cold.
dialogue-bosshunter-intro-final-text: Take this crystal. It will reveal the distance to the warden and take a sliver of blood each time.
dialogue-bosshunter-final-text: Good. The path is clear for now. If you need another hunt, you know where to find me.
no-quest-available-bosshunter: No hunt is available right now.
no-quest-available-bosshunter-cooldown: A new hunt will be available in {0} day(s). Target rotation in {1} day(s).
bosshunt-rotation-info: Boss hunt target rotation in {0} day(s).
innkeeper-firstimpression-desc: The innkeeper dislikes noise and doesn't trust words. He judges people by what they do. Do a short job nearby, and he'll hand you supplies without extra talk. This job is available only once.
innkeeper-firstimpression-journal-text: The innkeeper spoke in short, sharp sentences. He said he doesn't give work to everyone—he tests first. The job is simple: travel a bit on foot and deal with the target he assigns. No noise. Then return.
innkeeper-quietpatrol-desc: At night, something's always rustling around the inn. The innkeeper hates trouble at his doorstep. Walk the area, put down what comes too close, and don't make a scene. He pays in supplies. His work rotates about once a month.
innkeeper-quietpatrol-journal-text: The innkeeper told you to make a round. At night, something's always rustling around the inn. He wants it quiet at his doorstep. Go on foot, clear what he points at, then return.
innkeeper-badcustomers-desc: Some people come to an inn not for food, but for noise. The innkeeper can't stand them. Deal with what prowls nearby. He'll pay with something useful for the road. His work rotates about once a month.
innkeeper-badcustomers-journal-text: The innkeeper said: “Unwanted guests get sent away quietly.” Something is prowling near the inn. Deal with it without dragging trouble to the door. Then return.
innkeeper-silentdeliveries-desc: The innkeeper needs you to go farther than usual. Clear what blocks the road. Return without stories. He pays well for quiet work. His work rotates about once a month.
innkeeper-silentdeliveries-journal-text: He gave you an errand and watched as if expecting you to argue. This is not about strength—it's about keeping your head: go farther than usual on foot, clear the problem, and return without stories.
innkeeper-foxthief-desc: Something stole supplies from the inn. Small tracks, red fur. The innkeeper wants it to end quietly. Fix it and you'll get your share. His work rotates about once a month.
innkeeper-foxthief-journal-text: In the morning, the innkeeper noticed something missing. “A fox. Red. Bold. Stole something edible and ran into the brush.” Find the fox and end the problem. Then return.
innkeeper-cellarwatch-desc: The innkeeper keeps things in his cellar that should stay undisturbed. At night, you can hear scraping. He won't explain—he just wants the job done. Keep it quiet and he'll pay. His work rotates about once a month.
innkeeper-cellarwatch-journal-text: The innkeeper said: “If you hear creaking at night—it's not the wind.” Check around and push back whatever is drawn to the cellar. Quietly. Then return.
dialogue-innkeeper-firstimpression-final: You'll do. Take some food and bandages. If you want more work, come back later.
dialogue-innkeeper-quietpatrol-final-tex: It's quiet at my door. I like that. Take the supplies. No stories.
dialogue-innkeeper-badcustomers-final-te: No noise. Good. The bag and twine will help. The rest is a bonus.
dialogue-innkeeper-silentdeliveries-fina: You came back. Means your head is still attached. Bread and supplies. Remember: people here like silence.
dialogue-innkeeper-foxthief-final-text: There. The fox is fed—you will be too. Take it. And don't tell the whole town.
dialogue-innkeeper-cellarwatch-final-tex: The cellar should be quiet. Tonight it is. Bandages and supplies. Take them.
innkeeper-firstimpression-reward-journal: The test is done. The innkeeper decided you can handle quiet work. If you want more, his jobs rotate about once a month.
innkeeper-quietpatrol-reward-journal-tex: The area around the inn is quieter. The innkeeper prefers it that way. He paid you without extra words.
innkeeper-badcustomers-reward-journal-te: Fewer unwanted guests linger near the inn. The innkeeper noted you didn't make a scene. To him, that matters more than brute force.
innkeeper-silentdeliveries-reward-journa: The errand is done. He didn't ask for details—only results. Everything else is talk.
innkeeper-foxthief-reward-journal-text: The red shadow won't steal from the inn again. The innkeeper said, “Better this way.” And, as usual, pretended he didn't care.
innkeeper-cellarwatch-reward-journal-tex: The night is quieter. The innkeeper still won't say what he guards down there, but the cellar can ‘sleep’ again. He paid you right away.
dialogue-innkeeper-intro: Are you here to drink or to stare?
dialogue-innkeeper-whyso: Why so grim? You look like you've seen a ghost.
dialogue-innkeeper-close-answer: Don't slam the door. I hate that.
dialogue-innkeeper-whoareyou-answer: I run this inn. I see a lot of people. I don't like the noisy ones. Drunks, least of all. If you came to chatter, wrong door.
dialogue-innkeeper-aboutplace-answer: An inn. Roof, food, fire. And silence—if we're lucky. If you can behave, you're welcome.
dialogue-innkeeper-whyso-answer: Smiles are for people who don't owe anything. I don't know you yet. Don't push it—it's easier that way.
no-quest-available-innkeeper: Innkeeper: No work right now. Good.
innkeeper-missingmugs-desc: In the morning, some mugs are missing. No one confesses. The innkeeper wants you to handle it quietly. His work rotates about once a month.
innkeeper-missingmugs-journal-text: The innkeeper said, “Mugs don't walk away on their own.” Something is prowling around the inn at night. Deal with it—and make sure everything is in its place by morning.
innkeeper-talkingbarrel-desc: Something in the cellar is knocking, as if a barrel decided to talk. The innkeeper wants silence—and no stories. His work rotates about once a month.
innkeeper-talkingbarrel-journal-text: At night, you can hear it from the cellar: knocking and scraping. The innkeeper said, “This is not a joke. Make it stop.”
innkeeper-doorposter-desc: Someone is leaving notes on the inn's door that make the innkeeper's eye twitch. He won't read them—he just wants it to stop. His work rotates about once a month.
innkeeper-doorposter-journal-text: Another note on the door. The innkeeper said, “One more time, and I'll go out there myself.” Make sure they stop writing.
innkeeper-nightrunhunt-desc: The innkeeper doesn't like torches on the doorstep at night. Too much light brings eyes and teeth. Make a quick run through the dark and put down what stalks the road. This is not a regular job. Do it at night.
innkeeper-nightrunhunt-journal-text: He spoke low: “Run the roads at night. Quietly. No lantern parade.” Cover ground on foot and deal with what follows the light. Then return before dawn.
innkeeper-raccoonraid-desc: Wolves have been circling near the inn at night. Guests are jumpy and animals won't settle. The innkeeper wants them gone. Keep it quick, keep it quiet.
innkeeper-raccoonraid-journal-text: Wolves are prowling too close to the inn. I need to drive them off before someone ends up as a meal.
innkeeper-quietblade-title: Innkeeper: The Right Kind of Work
innkeeper-quietblade-desc: Sometimes the innkeeper needs a problem solved far from the inn—quietly, with no witnesses and no stories. Go far. Remove what he points to. Come back without boasting. He rewards useful people.
innkeeper-quietblade-journal-text: He didn't look up: “If you want to be useful—go. Farther than usual.” Two targets. No noise. Return when it's done.
innkeeper-nightjog-desc: They say night walks are good for your health. Take a walk... far away. Very far. And don't let me see you until dawn. I'll pay for the trouble.
innkeeper-nightjog-journal-text: The innkeeper sent me on a 'night jog'. I think he just got tired of me. I need to walk 10,000 meters before dawn.
innkeeper-nightjog-reward-journal-text: The night walk is over. I'm back. The innkeeper silently handed me some food. I don't think he expected me to return.
dialogue-innkeeper-nightjog-final-text: You're back. Alive. Well, what do you know. Here, you earned it.
innkeeper-nightmantle-desc:
The innkeeper watches you in silence, as if counting every job you've done. Then he nods: you've proven you can finish quiet work without stories.

One last test: no speeches — he'll name a couple of targets. How many will be up to chance.
innkeeper-nightmantle-journal-text:
He called me over without explanation. The test isn't over yet. The innkeeper handed me a list of targets — prowlers on the roads and outskirts. How many there will be is up to chance.

If I do it clean, I'll get his mark.
dialogue-innkeeper-nightmantle-final-tex:
People love talking about "heroes". Talk makes me sick. You didn't talk. You worked.

Take this pin. It's simple, but I don't hand these to strangers. Wear it—and keep a low profile. And remember: it's not decoration. It's a mark.
innkeeper-nightmantle-reward-journal-tex: The innkeeper gave me a plain silver pin. Not for looks — for work. I think I'm no longer just hired hands to him. I'm one of his.
dialogue-innkeeper-missingmugs-final-tex: The mugs are in place. Means the night was quiet. Take the supplies. And don't ask questions.
dialogue-innkeeper-talkingbarrel-final-t: It's quiet now. Good. Take this. If anyone asks, you heard nothing.
dialogue-innkeeper-doorposter-final-text: No notes. Better this way. Take the supplies. Let them write at their own homes from now on.
dialogue-innkeeper-nightrunhunt-final-te: Night roads are for those who can keep their head. You did. Take this and don't brag about it.
dialogue-innkeeper-raccoonraid-final-tex: It's quieter now. Means you did it. Take this.
dialogue-innkeeper-quietblade-final-text: You went far. Came back. Didn't make noise. That's the right kind of work. Take it.
innkeeper-missingmugs-reward-journal-tex: The mugs no longer ‘disappear’ on their own. The innkeeper was pleased you didn't make a scene.
innkeeper-talkingbarrel-reward-journal-t: The cellar fell silent. The patrons were left without a show. The innkeeper said that's how it should be.
innkeeper-doorposter-reward-journal-text: The notes on the door have stopped appearing. The innkeeper handed over the supplies and pretended it was just another day.
innkeeper-nightrunhunt-reward-journal-te: The roads felt quieter after the run. The innkeeper approved—without changing his tone. Night work is different. He only offers it rarely.
innkeeper-raccoonraid-reward-journal-tex: The wolves stopped circling the inn. The innkeeper paid without extra words.
innkeeper-quietblade-reward-journal-text: The errand is done. No witnesses, no stories. The innkeeper seemed satisfied. For him, that's praise.
dialogue-treasurer-intro: The Treasurer straightens his ledgers and, without looking up, begins in a dry tone: “Name? Purpose of visit? Grounds for being on Crossroads territory? Don’t pause — I’m timing your speech.”
dialogue-treasurer-openquests: I need the Surveyors’ services. And yes, it’s urgent.
dialogue-treasurer-openquests-confirm: “Urgent is when a report is missing a signature. Fine. State your request and on what grounds you think you qualify.”
dialogue-treasurer-paperwork: About the paperwork. Which forms, deadlines, and where do I sign?
dialogue-treasurer-paperwork-answer:
“First the application, then the boundary agreement, then the payment sheet, then the correction register if you botched the first form. Yes, those are different folders.” He shifts the stacks like they’re fragile machinery.

“Deadlines: same day if you bring everything before noon and don’t mix ink colors. Tomorrow if you make me confirm three times that your name is spelled the same everywhere. And yes, you sign every page. Even the blank ones. That is the rule.”
dialogue-treasurer-whyquiz-answer:
“Because people confuse north with east and call it ‘creative interpretation.’ Land doesn’t tolerate creativity; it tolerates rulers.” He nods at a pile of maps.

“If you don’t understand that a boundary is coordinates, not a mood, you’ll argue with neighbors, then with me, then with the court. The exam is cheaper than court. For you and for my nerves.”
dialogue-treasurer-boundaries: Any rules for boundaries, so I don’t get in trouble?
dialogue-treasurer-boundaries-answer:
“Do not place boundary stones on someone else’s stones. Do not ‘nudge’ a stake because ‘it looks nicer.’ Do not blame mistakes on the wind. Wind moves dust, not signatures.”

“If borders are disputed — call a surveyor, not your friends with picks. If you want to expand — pay, don’t press. I’m no saint, but I prefer things within the rules. At least those I can count.”
dialogue-treasurer-closechoice: I’ll go before you make me sign three copies.
dialogue-treasurer-close-answer: “Good. Paper tolerates everything; my nerves do not. Next.”
treasurer-buy-allowance-desc: Increase land allowance by 100000 m³. Payment is in rusty gears.
treasurer-buy-allowance-accepted: Treasurer: I’ll verify your current limits before payment.
treasurer-buy-allowance-reward: Treasurer: Approved. +100000 m³ to land allowance.
treasurer-buy-maxareas-desc: Increase maximum land claim areas by 1. Payment is in rusty gears.
treasurer-buy-maxareas-accepted: Treasurer: I’ll verify your current limits before payment.
dialogue-treasurer-survey: I want land claim rights. What do I need?
dialogue-treasurer-survey-start: Before I grant you access to the Surveyors’ Guild services, you will pass a mandatory survey. Twenty questions. Multiple choice. Mistakes are allowed, but then don't complain about ‘unfair borders’.
dialogue-treasurer-survey-end: The Treasurer nods dryly: “Answers recorded. If you scored enough correct ones — we will process the documents. If not — repeat until you learn to respect geometry.”
dialogue-treasurer-survey-final-text: “Now that is better. At least you understand that a right angle is not a metaphor.” Access to the Surveyors’ services is open. Get to work — and don't lose your gears.
no-quest-available-treasurer: Treasurer: No procedures are required right now. Stop hovering.
no-quest-available-treasurer-cooldown: Treasurer: Come back later. Per regulations — in {0} day(s).
treasurer-survey-desc: The Treasurer does not grant land marking rights to just anyone. First — the mandatory Surveyors’ Guild survey. Twenty questions. Some sound absurd, but paperwork does not accept that as an argument.
treasurer-survey-reward: Treasurer: Survey passed. Access to land claim processing is open.
treasurer-q1: 1) The founder of the Surveyors’ Guild, Old Bartimus, is famous for:
treasurer-q1-a: a) Inventing the first compass made of rusty gears.
treasurer-q1-b: b) Measuring all land using only a pair of stretched socks.
treasurer-q1-c: c) Defeating the Great Dragon of Disorder at chess.
treasurer-q1-d: d) Never washing to ‘preserve the natural scent of the territory’.
treasurer-q2-a: a) A crossed shovel and compass.
treasurer-q2-b: b) A square inside a circle inside a triangle.
treasurer-q2-c: c) A smiling sun holding a ruler.
treasurer-q2-d: d) A tangled ball of measuring tape.
treasurer-q3: 3) Which of these materials, per the Charter, is NOT considered ‘noble’ for marking plot corners?
treasurer-q3-d: d) A piece of petrified wood.
treasurer-q4: 4) What do surveyors supposedly shout when they find a perfectly flat plain?
treasurer-q4-d: d) ‘The horizon is as straight as a string!’
treasurer-q5: 5) Volume three of the ‘Great Treatise on Borders’ is mostly about:
treasurer-q5-a: a) An argument with the cartographers’ guild about line thickness.
treasurer-q5-b: b) Classifying boundary stones by how ‘cozy’ they are.
treasurer-q5-c: c) Mathematical calculations for spherical plots in a vacuum.
treasurer-q5-d: d) A recipe for herbal tea they drink while measuring.
treasurer-q6: 6) What must a surveyor apprentice always carry when going into the field?
treasurer-q6-a: a) A spare pair of socks.
treasurer-q6-b: b) A book of love poetry.
treasurer-q7: 7) The phrase ‘The rusty gear spins but doesn't catch’ means:
treasurer-q7-b: b) Someone fusses but gets nothing done.
treasurer-q7-c: c) It's time to replace the measuring tool.
treasurer-q7-d: d) Someone stole the drafting oil.
treasurer-q8: 8) The Guild’s main holiday is called:
treasurer-q8-b: b) The Festival of Perpendicular Lines.
treasurer-q8-c: c) The Week of the Lost Surveyor.
treasurer-q8-d: d) The Feast of Harvested Angles.
treasurer-q9: 9) The ‘Swamp of Unclear Borders’ was drained and partitioned thanks to:
treasurer-q9-a: a) The heroic efforts of seventy surveyors.
treasurer-q9-b: b) The fact that the mosquitoes simply ran out.
treasurer-q9-c: c) An accidental oil leak from a giant machine that formed a solid road.
treasurer-q9-d: d) The decision to rename it ‘Meadow of Exemplary Outlines’.
treasurer-q10: 10) Upon witnessing unlawful land grabbing, a true surveyor should:
treasurer-q10-a: a) Immediately draft a report in three ink colors.
treasurer-q10-b: b) Politely ask if the violator needs help with precise measurements.
treasurer-q10-c: c) Loudly whistle into a special pipe.
treasurer-q10-d: d) Place a ‘boundary stone of disapproval’ under cover of night.
treasurer-q11: 11) The most terrible sin for a surveyor is:
treasurer-q11-b: b) Mixing up north and south on an official plan.
treasurer-q11-d: d) Wearing striped socks with a checked shirt.
treasurer-q12: 12) The legendary instrument ‘Compass of Eternity’ was lost because:
treasurer-q12-a: a) A metal-hungry troll ate it.
treasurer-q12-b: b) It was put in a visible place and then forgotten where that place was.
treasurer-q12-c: c) It was so precise it measured its own insignificance and vanished.
treasurer-q12-d: d) The mages’ guild confiscated it for ‘more important circles’.
treasurer-q13: 13) What do surveyors drink during the ‘Spirit Level Break’?
treasurer-q13-b: b) Water with an exact number of lemon drops.
treasurer-q14: 14) If a local hedgehog stares at you while measuring, it means:
treasurer-q14-a: a) The plot will be fertile.
treasurer-q14-b: b) The hedgehog is checking your precision.
treasurer-q14-c: c) You are standing on its path to worms.
treasurer-q14-d: d) It's a good sign, but only if it looks north.
treasurer-q15: 15) Who do surveyors consider their talisman?
treasurer-q15-b: b) A crane (for its straight flight line).
treasurer-q15-c: c) A snail (for its consistent course).
treasurer-q15-d: d) An earthworm (it loosens the soil).
treasurer-q16-b: b) ‘Even infinity can be divided into plots’.
treasurer-q16-c: c) ‘A lost book is just waiting to be found again in a different order’.
treasurer-q17: 17) Before laying a cornerstone, it must be:
treasurer-q17-c: c) Shown to three independent observers.
treasurer-q17-d: d) Used to boil a kettle and brew tea.
treasurer-q18: 18) The phrase ‘There is wind walking through his blueprints’ means the person:
treasurer-q18-c: c) Stores plans in a perforated tube.
treasurer-q19: 19) What is NOT kept in the Hall of Old Maps?
treasurer-q19-a: a) A continent map drawn on the back of a lunch menu.
treasurer-q19-b: b) A globe where everything is land.
treasurer-q19-c: c) Blueprints of a flying machine by the great Leonardo.
treasurer-q19-d: d) A plan of a city that was never built.
treasurer-q20: 20) Complete the guild blessing phrase: ‘May your borders be sharp, your angles straight, and...’
treasurer-survey-result-0: The Treasurer exhales like a seized gear: “Your answers raise two questions: how did you get here, and why are you negotiating with paperwork at all? This isn’t failure, it’s a collapse. Start over from zero — and stop arguing with the ruler.”
treasurer-survey-result-8: “Half wrong. You have intuition, but you’re swinging it into a wall. Land prefers precision, not guesses. You’ll retake it. Next time, count instead of hoping.”
treasurer-survey-result-12: The Treasurer notes something in the ledger: “Minimum met. You understand boundaries, even if it pains you. We’ll process the documents, but I’d still reread the charter. Just in case.”
treasurer-survey-result-17: He finally looks up: “A rare case. You don’t just recall the form, you grasp the meaning. That is competence. Your papers will be ready without extra delay.”
